It seems pertinent to mention that probably 90 to 95 per cent of the pro¬
grams of NAEB University stations are now directed to adults# Through such an
excellent series like ’’Aging Successfully” NAEB is helping its member stations to
render an important adult education service to their listeners# We hope the NAEB
will increase the number of such programs# Wa do believe that the MEB might well
call upon specialists in adult education for assistance in selecting future adult
education programs# We suggest the Adult Education Association of the United States
of America^ the adult education department of the National Educational Association^
and the office of the Specialist for General Adult and Post-High School Education/

II* NETWORK GENERAL SERVICES
Our discussion of general NAEB services includes both radio and television
although cnly a handful of university stations now are active in television# We
are hopeful that Ohio State University eventually will be concerned with both broad¬
cast media*
Determining Audience Needs
Returning to the adult education people mentioned earlier, perhaps these
specialists also might be able to assist NAEB university station personnel to be¬
come better acquainted with some of the techniques for determining the adult
education interests and needs in the geographical areas served by their stations#
For exarrple, one way to learn adult education needs is to study census data in
terms of identifying needs of various groups in the area covered by a radio station#
"Aging Successfully" illustrates an appeal to a particular group#«. the older folks.
Another technique is to work with advisory groups# Perhaps adult educa¬
tion specialists can help NAEB members learn how best to organize and work with
advisory groups in (1) identifying adult education interests and needs in their
station’s service area; (2) determining the objectives of the programs which they
select to serve those interests and needs; (3) planning the content and format
of the selected programs; and (I4) evaluating the effectiveness of the programs in
meeting those interests and needs# It might be mentioned that one possible
weakness with advisory groups in the past has been the failure to include prospec¬
tive listeners in their membership#
